Articles.Content:
I'll keep it simple: build an insane winged aircraft and transport one Kerbal to a controlled landing on the Island airstrip. Your aircraft *must* then be able to take off again, under its own power.

Scoring:

[*]Launch TWR: 1 point per hundredth (so a 5.5 would score 550 points, a 25.00 would score 2500, 25.99 scores 2599. A TWR of less than 1 scores nothing).

[*]Weight: Scores per 1/100 launch ton: 1 point. So 4 tons scores 400 points, 4.99 tons scores 499 points.

[*]Max. airspeed (F3 mission report), 1 point per m/s (refer to restrictions for altitude restriction)

[*]Part Count: 1 point per part.

[*]Plant flag in the Island: 1000 points.

[*]Return to Base: Fly back to KSC and land safely, 1000 points (only counts if you have planted a flag on the Island during this mission).

-100 points for every whole minute of mission elapsed time.

Score is completely negated if you crash or your Kerbal dies.

Normal "no exploits" rules apply.

- No clipping.

- No infinite fuel.

- No hack gravity.

- No unbreakable joints.

- No welding.

- No zero-weight parts.

- No drag hacking except standard-mod procedural fairings.

- No parts jettisoning.

- No decouplers.

- Flight ceiling is 15km.

ANY structural mod permitted subject to the above restrictions.

Proofs: Screenshots ([*]), .craft file on request

**Rules subject to slight adjustment as I attempt this challenge myself.

Edited January 30, 2014 by jacobgong

yes they do have weight on the ground/when deployed. Squad (stock) medium struts weigh 0.1 each, the heavy ones weigh 1.0 and the light ones 0.05. I think.. let me check... yes, stock gear weighs 0.5. Every part you add decreases TWR for any given engine configuration. Go ahead, try it with any non-masshacked part.
